{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3365325,"name":"","username":"cwm9","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/898d66/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T20:51:00.749Z","cooked":"

I understand what brake and coast mode are, but I’m confused about exactly when they apply.

The REVLib documentation that they apply when the motor is considered “idle”. They state that the motor is idle when “neutral signal (no motor movement)” and when the robot is disabled.

Now, disabled is obvious, but I’m still a little confused on the “neutral signal” part.

Suppose I have a velocity pid set up and set the velocity PID to 0. Is this considered an idle state, or will the PID actively try to maintain a 0 velocity?

i.e., if a motor is currently running with velocity PID 200 RPM and I set the velocity PID to 0 RPM, I can envision several scenarios:

1: the controller immediately shorts the leads to bring the velocity to 0 using brake mode
2: the controller actively reverses the voltage, and when the motor stops moving, it shorts the leads
3: the motor actively reverses the voltage to bring the velocity to 0, then enters coast mode and allows the motor to be pushed around
4: the controller immediately enters coast mode and allows the motor to come to a rest by itself
5: Because the controller is in velocity PID mode, neither brake nor coast are ever applied. The PID actively applies a reverse voltage to the motor to bring the motor to a stop, then actively manages the voltage to keep that position.

Further, if brake mode does apply to the PID, how does the sparkmax decide what “stopped” is? If I set the velocity near to 0 (say, .001 RPM), do I get different behavior than setting exactly it to 0.0?

The motor has several control modes:
kCurrent
kDutyCycle
kPosition
kSmartMotion
kSmartVelocity
kVelocity
kVoltage

It would be good to know what defines idle for these modes.

Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-04-18T20:59:14.396Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":30,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":185.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":463272,"topic_slug":"what-exactly-defines-idle-for-a-sparkmax","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50849,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/what-exactly-defines-idle-for-a-sparkmax/463272/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3365329,"name":"Technologyman00","username":"Technologyman00","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/technologyman00/{size}/178178_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T20:53:12.231Z","cooked":"

Idle is when the motor controller is not trying to output power.

A velocity PID of 0 isn’t necessarily no power. If it is spinning the velocity PID will attempt to make it not spin by putting power to slow it down

So, in position PID mode, once the position is attained, if no power output is required, brake mode will be applied, and then if the encoder value changes, brake mode will be disengaged and the motor will again try to achieve the programmed position?

For many PID applications, it would be very hard or impossible for the position to be maintained exactly at the setpoint — for instance, if driven by a magnetic encoder, noise would constantly keep the output different from the setpoint.

Is there a way to set a deadband for the error so brake mode is kept on unless the error exceeds a preset level?

But if you are using position mode to suspend a weight. Correctly tuned, the PID will give an non zero output to hold position. Neither brake nor coast will be used for that.

I think this might be true but only for feedfoward. Unless it never reached the setpoint and is just barely below the setpoint it would have turned off at one instance and I presume going into idle.

Positioning with a load… Zero speed is rarely 0 output. The controller switch to brake mode at zero output would seem to me to be a distraction. But that is just me.
